reinforcements.new_element_id: works-005 (Scale Agent-Mediated Trust by Encoding It Into Platform Artifacts)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: works-004 (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming)
reinforcements.similarity: Both identify the agent-to-platform trust transfer as the highest-risk transition in the host journey. The existing element (andreas-call + Kahneman) prescribes priming the digital experience from within the human interaction and echoing the call on the platform. The new element (mahesh-call + Cold Start Theory) prescribes encoding Bryant's trust-building statements into reusable platform artifacts (Trust Dossier, Guarantee Dashboard, handoff notes).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Andreas-call evidence: the call ends with personal commitments (5:27-6:11), and the platform is never mentioned. Mahesh-call evidence: Bryant explains vetting, guarantees, and protocols verbally, and the platform is mentioned once as a delivery channel (05:05). Kahneman's priming research explains WHY trust transfers fail (unprimed stimulus). Cold Start Theory explains the SCALABILITY constraint (Butterfield handled 10,000 tweets, but this does not scale past the tipping point). Combined insight: trust transfer is both a cognitive design problem (Kahneman) AND a network scaling problem (Chen). The solution must address both: prime for the transition AND encode the trust for reuse at scale.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: communicates-006 (Agent Continuity Frame: The Platform Speaks as an Extension of the Person)
reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe that the platform's first screen must carry the agent's identity and reference the specific call. The existing element prescribes agent-attributed notifications and a persistent agent identity. The new element prescribes a personalized handoff document with agent note, pre-populated property details, guest profile, and single CTA.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Andreas expects to deal with Bryant, not the platform (5:44: 'You can just email me at any time'). New evidence: Mahesh will arrive at the platform with trust concentrated in Bryant, and the platform must echo the call's information structure. Kahneman's priming and Cold Start Theory's scaling constraint converge: the agent's voice must be present on the platform AND the handoff must contain call-specific data. Combined: the handoff screen IS the agent continuity frame made concrete with personalized data.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: feels-002 (The Relief of Guaranteed Income: Show the Money, Then Show Why It's Safe)
reinforcements.similarity: Both target the emotional arc of financial safety as the prerequisite for host commitment. The existing element (from andreas-call) identifies the tension-relief arc: show the total first, then the guarantee mechanism, with a 300ms delay between. The new element (from mahesh-call) prescribes that protection status must render first on every commitment screen, before any other content.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Andreas stops interrogating after the guarantee explanation (3:51). Mahesh asks about financial protection three separate times (02:17, 10:45, 12:04). Both hosts need the same emotional resolution, but Mahesh is more persistent -- he re-probes because he has a management company adding risk perception. Cold Start Theory adds: hosts are the hard side who 'will try competitive products to compare.' Combined insight: the guarantee must not only produce relief (Kahneman) but also outcompete the competitor's implicit safety of familiarity (Cold Start). The guarantee needs to be louder, earlier, and more unconditional than previously prescribed.

reinforcements.new_element_id: works-004 (Define and Instrument the Three-Month Atomic Network Stability Threshold)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: behaves-006 (Notification as Continuation, Not Interruption) [active_lease/retention states]
reinforcements.similarity: Both address the active lease period as a critical retention window requiring proactive platform engagement. The existing element prescribes notifications as self-contained action units with exception-based cadence during active leases. The new element prescribes a Network Health Score with deliberate engagement moments at weeks 2, 6, and 10, plus a Lease Performance Summary at month 3.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Andreas prefers email (5:44). Mahesh's lease is explicitly conditional on 3-month performance (03:26). Kahneman's ego depletion means batched weekly summaries are better than individual notifications. Cold Start Theory's Slack threshold (2,000 messages = 93% retention) provides the theoretical framework for defining Split Lease's equivalent. Combined: the notification-as-continuation pattern is the delivery mechanism; the stability threshold is the content strategy. They are complementary layers.

reinforcements.new_element_id: works-001 (Absorb the Hard Side's Risk Completely Before Asking for Commitment)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: communicates-003 (Trust Credential Stack: Process Before Promise, Verification Before Claim)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address how trust information should be structured for hosts who demand evidence. The existing element prescribes mechanism-first, conclusion-second ordering (credit check before guarantee claim). The new element prescribes complete risk absorption BEFORE every commitment request -- guarantees embedded in price display, proposal cards leading with protection status.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Andreas responds to the trust mechanism with his own verifiable standard (4:06: 'excellent credit on every single tenant'). Mahesh circles back to financial risk three separate times. Kahneman explains the causal chain that makes trust work. Cold Start Theory explains why the hard side requires risk elimination, not just risk reduction. Combined: the trust credential stack is the information architecture; risk absorption is the process pattern that ensures the stack appears before every ask.

reinforcements.new_element_id: works-006 (Use the First Successful Lease to Tip Adjacent Networks)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: works-001 (Atomic Network Assembly: Specific Tenant-Property Match Before Platform Onboarding) [from 2026-02-19_0802 run]
reinforcements.similarity: Both address how to form and expand atomic networks. The existing element (from dimitri-call + coldstart-network-effects) prescribes assembling the first atomic network by presenting the specific match before platform onboarding. The new element prescribes leveraging a successful first lease to tip adjacent networks through management company pathway reuse and referral mechanisms.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Dimitri's atomic network formation is a single-deal conversion sprint (1-week window). Mahesh's atomic network includes a management company gatekeeper that, once cleared, creates a reusable pathway for adjacent hosts. Combined: the first atomic network must be assembled quickly (Dimitri pattern) AND designed for domino reuse (Mahesh pattern). The management company pathway is the hinge between the two.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: works-004 (Remote Host Visibility Loop: Overseas Monitoring Without Active Management) [from 2026-02-19_0802 run]
reinforcements.similarity: Both address the host's need for cumulative visibility during active leases. The existing element prescribes weekly status updates with cleaning photos and payment confirmations for remote hosts. The new element prescribes a 12-segment progress bar with milestone markers at weeks 4, 8, 12 and three aggregate KPIs (income, on-time rate, incidents).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Dimitri will be abroad for 3 months and needs passive monitoring. Mahesh's lease is explicitly a 3-month stability test. Both need the same core data (payments received, property status, incident count) but framed differently: Dimitri needs reassurance across distance, Mahesh needs evidence for the renewal decision. Combined: the Lease Health Meter is the visual component; the Remote Host Visibility Loop is the push delivery mechanism. The progress bar adds bounded journey framing that the visibility loop lacks.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: behaves-004 (Save-and-Resume: The Platform Remembers Where You Stopped) [from original library]
reinforcements.similarity: Both address what happens when the host returns to the platform after a gap. The existing element ensures multi-step processes preserve progress across sessions. The new element ensures the first platform visit mirrors the call's information structure. They are sequential: the handoff bridge handles the first visit, save-and-resume handles subsequent visits.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Andreas is a multitasking host who may be interrupted (0:15: building a bar). Mahesh's trust gap is between the call and the first platform interaction. Combined: the handoff bridge (new) must work seamlessly with save-and-resume (existing). If the host visits the handoff screen, closes it before acting, and returns days later, the handoff data must persist per the save-and-resume pattern. This is a dependency, not a conflict.

contradictions.existing_element_id: looks-005 (Green Trust Badges: Accent Color Reserved Exclusively for Verified and Guaranteed Elements)
contradictions.conflict: The new element prescribes a deep purple (#31135D) solid-fill Protection Status bar as the highest-contrast visual anchor for guarantees. The existing element reserves forest green (#2d5a3d) exclusively for verified and guaranteed elements, with green trust badges as the visual shorthand for 'this has been verified.' These two patterns assign different colors to the same semantic category (guarantees/protection), which would create visual incoherence -- is the guarantee purple or green?
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The existing green-badge pattern is from the original library (1 lens, Kahneman + andreas-call) and uses the tokens.json accent color (#2d5a3d). The new purple-first pattern uses production CSS colors (#31135D) per the known token drift documented in MEMORY.md ('Production uses purple palette, NOT green from tokens.json'). The purple palette has stronger evidence because it matches the actual production system. The green palette is from tokens.json which is known to be drifted.
contradictions.recommendation: Resolve by adopting the purple production palette for ALL guarantee/protection elements. The Protection Status bar uses #31135D as prescribed by the new element. Trust badges should be updated from green (#2d5a3d on #e8f0eb) to purple (secondary-purple on protocol-surface #F7F2FA) to maintain semantic consistency with the production palette. Reserve green only for success states (completed actions, confirmed saves) if green appears in production at all. This is a systemic token alignment that affects the entire library.

contradictions.existing_element_id: looks-001 (Warm Surface Continuity: The First 2 Seconds Must Feel Like the Same Conversation)
contradictions.conflict: The existing element prescribes bg (#f6f4f0) as the warm off-white background for all pages. The new element prescribes a special handoff background rgb(252,250,255) -- a purple-tinted warm white -- for the first-visit handoff screen, to create a sense of specialness. These two warm-white values are very close but semantically different: one is the universal background, the other is a special-occasion variant with a purple tint. Using both creates a subtle inconsistency if the host navigates between the handoff screen and other pages.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The existing element's bg (#f6f4f0) is from tokens.json and has 1 lens of evidence. The new element's rgb(252,250,255) is from the production purple palette. The purple tint is intentional to align with the production brand, but introduces a second warm-white that tokens.json does not recognize. Evidence strength is roughly equal.
contradictions.recommendation: Accept the purple-tinted handoff background as a semantic variant (--handoff-bg) but ensure it transitions smoothly to the standard background after the handoff screen dissolves into the dashboard. The transition should use a crossfade (400ms) so the host does not perceive a color jump. Add --handoff-bg to tokens.json as a documented semantic alias.

contradictions.new_element_id: looks-001 through looks-006 (all visual patterns from this run)
contradictions.existing_element_id: looks-001 through looks-007 (all visual patterns from original library)
contradictions.conflict: The original library's visual system is built on tokens.json, which uses Instrument Serif, Outfit, IBM Plex Mono, and a warm green accent (#2d5a3d). The new run's visual system is built on the production purple palette with Inter, DM Sans, and purple hierarchy (#31135D, rgb(109,49,194), rgb(140,104,238)). These are two different design systems. Typography families are entirely different (Instrument Serif vs. DM Sans, Outfit vs. Inter, IBM Plex Mono does not appear in the new run). Color palettes are fundamentally different (warm green accent vs. purple accent).
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The tokens.json system was established in the first run (andreas-call + Kahneman, 1 lens). The production purple system reflects the actual deployed style guide per MEMORY.md. The production system has operational authority (it is what users actually see). The tokens.json system has theoretical authority (it is the documented design token source). This is the known token drift flagged in MEMORY.md.
contradictions.recommendation: This is the systemic token drift issue. Recommendation: (1) Update tokens.json to reflect the production purple palette as the canonical system. (2) All library elements referencing green accent, Instrument Serif, and Outfit should be flagged for visual update in a future coherence pass. (3) New runs should use the production palette exclusively. (4) The existing library elements' functional logic (information hierarchy, progressive disclosure, trust credential ordering) remains valid regardless of which color palette implements them.

extensions.new_element_id: works-002 (Design for the Institutional Gatekeeper as a First-Class Network Participant)
extensions.gap_filled: No existing library element addresses the management company / HOA / co-op board as a network participant. All prior host journey elements assume the host can decide unilaterally. Mahesh's call reveals that for professionally managed properties, the atomic network includes a third-party gatekeeper whose approval is a blocking dependency. This is an entirely new pattern that extends the library's host journey model from [Host + Guest + Platform] to [Host + Gatekeeper + Guest + Platform].
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens (mahesh-call + Cold Start). The management company pattern is strongly evidenced in the call (04:25-04:30, 09:34) and theoretically grounded in Cold Start Theory's enterprise adoption parallel. However, we lack data on how common management-company-gated hosts are across the Split Lease population. If they represent a small minority, this element may be over-prioritized. Recommend validating with agent data on what percentage of hosts mention a management company or HOA.

extensions.gap_filled: No existing library element addresses the need to export guest information in a format consumable by a third party (management company, HOA). The library has extensive patterns for host-facing and guest-facing information display, but nothing for externally-facing export documents. This extends the library's information architecture from two audiences (host, guest) to three (host, guest, institutional gatekeeper).
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The export document pattern is novel to the library. Confidence is moderate: the need is clearly evidenced in Mahesh's call, but the specific format (PDF rental application) is an assumption about what management companies expect. Different management companies may have different format requirements, which would complicate a one-size-fits-all export.

extensions.new_element_id: communicates-003 (Layered Novelty Disclosure for Ghost Roommate Concept)
extensions.gap_filled: No existing library element addresses how to introduce a genuinely novel concept (ghost roommates) through progressive disclosure gated by the host's phase and readiness. The library has progressive disclosure patterns for visual weight (looks-006) and sequential input (behaves-002), but not for concept introduction where the concept itself is unfamiliar. This extends progressive disclosure from 'how much detail to show' to 'how much novelty to introduce.'
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The three-layer ghost roommate disclosure model is well-evidenced from Mahesh's dual response (economic interest + operational anxiety), but the specific layer boundaries (evaluation whisper, match preview card, active operations dashboard) are design hypotheses that need usability validation.

extensions.gap_filled: No existing library element models an external, asynchronous approval process as a first-class state machine within the platform's pipeline. The library has interaction states for on-platform actions (loading, error, success) but nothing for tracking an off-platform process (management company reviewing a document) as a visible pipeline stage. This extends the library's interaction model from synchronous platform actions to asynchronous external dependencies.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The state machine design (Package Not Yet Shared > Package Shared > Awaiting Approval > Approved/Denied) is logically sound but untested. The 5-business-day nudge timing is an assumption. The biggest risk is that management companies have wildly variable response times, making the countdown feel inaccurate.

extensions.new_element_id: behaves-007 (Adjacent Network Seed Prompt at Stability Threshold)
extensions.gap_filled: No existing library element addresses the post-lease referral mechanism as a deliberate network growth tool. The library focuses on converting individual hosts but has no pattern for converting a successful host into a seed for adjacent host acquisition. This extends the library from individual host conversion to network-level growth architecture.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The referral prompt timing (after 3-month stability threshold) is theoretically grounded in Cold Start Theory's domino effect, but the effectiveness of host-to-host referrals in the management company context is unvalidated. The pre-written message with management company approval reference is a strong hypothesis but needs A/B testing.

extensions.gap_filled: No existing library element addresses the three-party contractual structure disambiguation. The library addresses trust (who to trust) and guarantees (what is guaranteed) but not counterparty mapping (who handles what for each type of interaction). Mahesh's confusion at 11:27 reveals this as a genuine gap: the host cannot parse the multi-party arrangement from text alone.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The four-responsibility mapping (payments, protection, communication, disputes) is a simplification that may miss edge cases (e.g., ghost roommate adds a fourth party). However, the core insight -- that the host needs a spatial map, not a textual explanation -- is well-evidenced by Mahesh's fragmented attempt to articulate the question.

new_tokens_flagged: --primary-purple (#31135D): not in tokens.json, exists only in production Style-guide.md
--shadow-purple-sm (0 2px 4px rgba(49,19,93,0.2)): not in tokens.json (tokens.json shadows use rgba(26,23,20,x))
Inter font family: not in tokens.json (tokens.json uses Outfit)
DM Sans font family: not in tokens.json (tokens.json uses Instrument Serif)
--rounded-lg (8px), --rounded-full: tokens.json uses sm(6px), md(10px), lg(16px), full(9999px) -- values differ
token_compliance.recommendation: The production purple palette and production typography (Inter, DM Sans) are the correct tokens for new elements, per MEMORY.md documentation that 'Production uses purple palette (#31135D), NOT green (#2d5a3d) from tokens.json.' Recommendation: UPDATE tokens.json to include the production palette as the canonical system. The current tokens.json represents an outdated design direction. All new elements in this run correctly use production values. The library should be batch-updated to replace green-accent references with purple-accent references, and Instrument Serif/Outfit with DM Sans/Inter where appropriate. This is a one-time alignment task that should prevent token drift in future runs.

journey_emotion_map.assessment: Mahesh arrives with zero awareness of Split Lease. His emotional state is cautiously curious but anchored to Furnished Finder as a comparison point. The platform must not overwhelm with novelty.

The richest emotional phase. Mahesh is systematically probing for failure modes. Three separate risk inquiries (payment, deposit, damage) reveal vigilance as the dominant emotion. Vigilance must be resolved into safety before commitment.

The agent-to-platform transition. Emotional continuity from Bryant's call is critical. The target is forward momentum, not excitement -- the host should feel the conversation continuing, not restarting.

Mahesh has already described his property on the call. Re-entering data signals the platform was not listening. Pre-population creates the feeling of competence -- the host confirms rather than constructs.

The payment guarantee is the emotional anchor. Mahesh's rate ($2,600) is his own number. The guarantee makes it unconditional. Emotional peak: the moment the guarantee is embedded in the price display.

Mahesh must evaluate Ariel AND navigate his management company. The emotional arc splits: personal evaluation produces interest; management company gate produces anxiety about intermediary burden. Relief comes from the platform handling the export.
The 3-month stability test. Emotional target is calm, not excitement. Each completed week should feel like evidence accumulating. Ghost roommate operations (if opted in) require graduated confidence.

The renewal decision must feel evidence-based, not abstract. If the Lease Health dashboard has accumulated 12 weeks of positive data, the emotional state at renewal is quiet confidence. Referral readiness emerges from genuine satisfaction, not prompts.

arc_conflicts: CONFLICT: feels-003 (Graduated Confidence for Ghost Roommate) targets 'confidence' during evaluation, but feels-001 (Preemptive Safety Before the Ask) targets 'safety' during the same phase. These are not contradictory but could compete for emotional bandwidth if both ghost roommate disclosure and guarantee disclosure happen simultaneously. Resolution: guarantee information ALWAYS takes priority over ghost roommate information. The guarantee resolves the gating emotion (safety); ghost roommate is an optional upside that requires safety to be established first.

CONFLICT: feels-002 (Institutional Belonging) targets 'relief' during onboarding, while feels-004 (Warm Recognition) targets 'momentum' during onboarding. These are complementary but sequentially dependent: momentum must come first (the handoff screen), then relief follows (the management company export). If the host encounters the management company gate before feeling recognized, the burden overwhelms the momentum.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The end-to-end emotional arc for this lens follows a coherent trajectory: cautious curiosity (discovery) -> vigilance (evaluation) -> momentum through recognition (onboarding) -> competence through pre-population (listing) -> financial certainty through guarantees (pricing) -> informed control with gatekeeper support (proposal) -> calm accumulation (active lease) -> evidence-based retention. The arc's distinctive feature compared to other host runs is the management company gate, which introduces an anxiety spike during evaluation and proposal_mgmt that must be actively managed through the gatekeeper export pattern. Without the gatekeeper support, the emotional arc would stall at evaluation for professionally managed properties. The ghost roommate concept introduces a secondary emotional thread (curiosity -> anxiety -> graduated confidence) that runs alongside the primary guarantee thread. The two threads must be kept separate in the UI: guarantee resolves the primary emotion; ghost roommate addresses the secondary. Mixing them (showing ghost roommate economics alongside guarantee terms) would create emotional confusion.

discovery.notes: L0 provides rich context. L1 works-005 and works-006 touch discovery tangentially (agent trust transfer, adjacent networks). No dedicated discovery UI elements from this run. The library has strong discovery coverage from prior runs (works-001 System 1 Trust Gate, feels-001 Cognitive Ease).

evaluation.notes: The most densely covered phase. All six layers produced evaluation elements: risk absorption (works-001), gatekeeper design (works-002), ghost roommate transparency (works-003), risk-first IA (communicates-001), gatekeeper export (communicates-002), ghost roommate disclosure (communicates-003), vetting disclosure (communicates-006), counterparty clarity (communicates-007), guarantee visual (looks-001), gatekeeper document (looks-004), counterparty map (looks-006), preemptive risk reveal (behaves-001), management handoff (behaves-002), ghost roommate ladder (behaves-003), safety emotion (feels-001), institutional belonging (feels-002), graduated confidence (feels-003), structural clarity (feels-006). Mahesh's evaluation phase is the richest data source in this call.

onboarding.notes: Gatekeeper design (works-002), agent trust encoding (works-005), gatekeeper export (communicates-002), trust transfer IA (communicates-004), handoff visual (looks-002), gatekeeper document (looks-004), management handoff state machine (behaves-002), agent continuity bridge (behaves-004), institutional belonging (feels-002), warm recognition (feels-004).

listing_creation.notes: Gatekeeper design (works-002), trust transfer IA (communicates-004), handoff visual (looks-002), agent continuity bridge (behaves-004), warm recognition (feels-004). Less dense than evaluation because Mahesh's call does not deeply explore listing creation. Library has strong listing_creation coverage from prior runs.

proposal_mgmt.notes: Risk absorption (works-001), gatekeeper design (works-002), risk-first IA (communicates-001), gatekeeper export (communicates-002), vetting disclosure (communicates-006), counterparty clarity (communicates-007), guarantee visual (looks-001), gatekeeper document (looks-004), counterparty map (looks-006), preemptive risk reveal (behaves-001), management handoff (behaves-002), counterparty disambiguation (behaves-006), safety emotion (feels-001), institutional belonging (feels-002), structural clarity (feels-006).

active_lease.notes: Risk absorption (works-001), ghost roommate economics (works-003), stability threshold (works-004), adjacent networks (works-006), ghost roommate disclosure (communicates-003), cumulative evidence (communicates-005), counterparty clarity (communicates-007), guarantee visual (looks-001), ghost roommate visual layers (looks-003), lease health meter (looks-005), counterparty map (looks-006), ghost roommate ladder (behaves-003), lease health pulse (behaves-005), counterparty disambiguation (behaves-006), adjacent network seed (behaves-007), graduated confidence (feels-003), visible accumulation (feels-005), structural clarity (feels-006).

Retention coverage is moderate because the call does not reach the retention phase -- it is inferred from the 3-month conditional commitment.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The management company gatekeeper pattern (works-002) introduces a process that cuts across evaluation, onboarding, listing_creation, and proposal_mgmt. Layer 1 should consider whether a dedicated 'Gatekeeper Onboarding' sub-process is needed alongside the standard host onboarding process, or whether the existing host onboarding process can branch based on a management company flag.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Mahesh-call evidence that management company approval is a blocking dependency (04:25-04:30, 09:34). Cold Start Theory's enterprise adoption parallel. Question for L1: should the listing creation wizard include a 'Does your property have a management company?' branching question at Step 1 that activates the gatekeeper workflow?

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The systemic token drift between tokens.json (green/Instrument Serif/Outfit) and production (purple/DM Sans/Inter) affects ALL visual elements in the library. Layer 3 should be re-examined with the production palette as the canonical visual system. The current L3 output uses production tokens correctly, but existing library L3 elements use the outdated tokens.json palette.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: MEMORY.md documents the drift: 'tokens.json uses warm green accent (#2d5a3d) but production uses purple (#31135D).' The coherence report identifies this as a critical contradiction. Recommend a library-wide L3 re-alignment pass using the production palette.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The emotional arc check reveals a potential bandwidth conflict between safety (feels-001) and confidence (feels-003) during the evaluation phase. Layer 5 should explicitly define the emotional priority ordering: guarantee-driven safety resolves first, then ghost-roommate confidence can begin. The current L5 output treats them as parallel; they should be sequential.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Mahesh asks about the payment guarantee (10:45) BEFORE engaging with ghost roommate details. His emotional sequence is: resolve financial safety first, then consider optional upside. L5 should mirror this sequence: safety emotions gate confidence emotions.
